title: Anyone else think Kindred would be a more interesting champ if Wolf was just as relevant as Lamb?
body:
Kindred is such an interesting pair in their lore, and in their theme. I played them a few times, and the fact that Wolf is literally just a W is disheartening. He could have been so much more. 

Kindred could have been a new tag-team champ, like Jayce, or Nidalee, or Gnar. Lamb could have been what she is now -- someone who's good at kiting and whittling champs down, but Wolf could have been some more aggressive champ that force-switches when attacking low-health champs. Like a diver. I dunno, I just feel bad for Wolf.

-------------

EDIT - Just a thought, but I think the new Warwick's kit would have worked really well with Wolf. More attack speed, good chase and a fear. Since people always fear the physical embodiment of death. 

EDIT - I also think Kindred's circles should be tuned around keeping enemies from running (More in an Illaoi E way, where she says, "Sure, you *CAN* leave, but~~~") and she should have some more opportunities to leap around her targets, like a ballerina. Graceful.

Q. Why would we make another tag team champ like Jayce?? That's not very diverse. 
A. Oh, please. A marksman with two circles doesn't add that much diversity, either. And at least Kindred's Q will never deal 10000000 damage from Mars.

Q. We tried it on Quinn, but Riot took that away!
A. That's not really a question,,, but Valor was literally just a melee Quinn that didn't add anything new but some changes to stats.

Lamb and Wolf are a different "duo" in a sense that they are not supposed to be a tag-team like Quinn and Valour where the 2 function together as 1, Lamb and Wolf are 1 that function as 2 instead. It was the goal of whoever it was to split themselves into 2 halves so that "he would always have a friend", it's thus unreasonable to merge Lamb and Wolf together mechanically because that would be just the same as before the split and thus self-defeating; and instead, they are supposed to be 2 distinct entities that complement each other. Therefore, the best way to work it out is by allowing the player to interchange between controlling Lamb and Wolf, while the unused one is still a support to the one currently in control; and together "they" are "one" champion called Kindred.

If you want another example that may or may not support what I was referring to, think about the colour design of Lamb and Wolf. What do you see? Lamb is white who wears a black mask, Wolf is black that wears a white mask; it clearly alludes to concepts like Taiji (the supreme pole/goal) where it's symbolised as one circle that is divided into two distinct halves, the white side has a black dot, and the black side has a white dot, and together they are One.

Hence the kit-swap idea similar to Elise and Jayce where you could control either as Lamb supported by Wolf or vice versa since lvl1 is more sounding, as opposed to say the kits similar to say Gnar (the 2 halves are not equal by default, though it is better than what we currently have but it's still not cool) or Lee Sin (2 halves merged back into 1, goes against the theme).

For example: The old kindred ult gave you trouble, but do you play the new kindred? She's kind of extremely ass right now and the ult change is partly responsible. I'd rather have a functioning yet somewhat difficult champion tbh

The thing is the lulu example is highly different because one again, any time you could cast ult before on someone self casting it would reach them anyways.  The only time you can't do it anymore is if someone is about to die outside your range and there is another ally between you two.  

Lulu ult is primarily a lifesave unless you happen to have something like a Yasuo on your team and are trying to combo.  The slow/knockup happens to be a bonus and unlike Kindred ult the effect is different for whomever you cast it on.  Yes there is an aoe component attached to an ally point and click but it very different from an ult that influences all allies the same and as such doesn't matter who you target with it.

Also I greatly preferred Kindred with the ult change over the original Kindred.  I found them to be much more streamlined because it felt like a needless mechanic.  The reason I don't play Kindred anymore (beyond not playing a ton of League right now and jungle/ADC being my two worst roles, I picked up kindred as a novelty Kalista is the only ADC I actually enjoy playing) is because they got nerfed into the ground.  For me the ult change felt like a power neutral change.  It was a nerf because you lost some flexibility, but it was also a buff because it streamlined the champion and made their abilities easier to use (Not easier I the sense of easy champion, easier in the sense that the ability didn't feel needlessly complicated while still performing the same role.)

The old ult only added difficulty to the champion in very rare cases.  However there are two types of difficulty, there is difficulty that adds to gameplay and difficulty that makes it harder to play that game.  Old kindred ult made her harder to use without actually adding to her gameplay at all.  An example would be if you had to solve a puzzle to use Taric's ult.  Sure, it adds difficulty, but it doesn't actually add to the gameplay, it hinders it.  In the same way Kindred ult only offered gameplay that it doesn't offer now in very rare and niche situations, while it hindered gameplay much more often.
